data.fullName: Cane River Creole National Historical Park
data.description: The Cane River region is home to a unique culture; the Creoles. Generations of the same families of workers, enslaved and tenant, and owners lived on these lands for over 200 years. The park tells their stories and preserves the cultural landscape of Oakland and Magnolia Plantations, two of the most intact Creole cotton plantations in the United States.
data.directionsInfo: To reach Oakland Plantation, take I-49 to Exit 127, Flora/Cypress. Head east on LA Highway 120 toward Cypress. Cross over LA Highway 1 onto LA Highway 494. The parking lot and entrance pavilion for Oakland is 4.5 miles east of Highway 1 on the left. To reach Magnolia Plantation, take I-49 to Exit 119, Cloutierville. Cross over LA Highway 1 onto LA Highway 119. Follow Highway 119 for 1.1 miles; the visitor parking lot will be on the right just before the plantation store.

operatingHours.description: The Texas & Pacific Railway Depot, Oakland Plantation and Magnolia Plantation are open Wednesday through Sunday from 9 am to 3:30 pm. Both self-guided and guided tours of the plantation grounds and outbuildings are available. In addition, the park store located in the Oakland Plantation store is open for shopping. The Oakland Plantation Main House is open for self-guided tours only on Saturday and Sunday from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Closed all federal holidays.
operatingHours.name: Oakland and Magnolia Plantations

addresses.line3: 1927 Remembrance Way, Natchitoches, LA 71457 (Texas & Pacific Railway Depot)

images.title: Oakland Plantation Quarters
images.altText: A small cabin sits beneath the branches of a Live Oak in the Oakland Plantation Quarters.
images.caption: One of two remaining cabins built for enslaved workers on Oakland Plantation. The cabin was lived in by sharecroppers into the 1960s.

images.title: Magnolia Plantation Overseer's House
images.altText: A raised Creole cottage surrounded by oak trees.
images.caption: Originally built as a hospital for the enslaved workers on Magnolia Plantation, this raised Creole cottage also served as home to the plantation Overseer.

images.title: Live Oak Trees
images.altText: The sunrise shines through Live Oak trees at Oakland Plantation.
images.caption: Live Oak trees at sunrise on Oakland Plantation.

images.title: Cabins in the Magnolia Plantation Quarters
images.altText: Brick cabins built to house enslaved workers, served as homes for tenant farmers into the 1960s.
images.caption: These brick cabins were built in the 1840s to house enslaved workers on Magnolia Plantation. Following Emancipation the cabins served as homes for tenant farmers.

images.title: Oak Allee
images.altText: Two rows of Live Oak trees stretch from the Cane River to the Oakland Plantation Main House.
images.caption: The Oak Allee, planted in the mid-1820s, stretches from the Cane River to the Oakland Plantation Main House.

images.title: Magnolia Plantation Cotton Gin and Press Barn
images.altText: This wood screw cotton press was used at Magnolia Plantation to form cotton into bales for market.
images.caption: The Magnolia Plantation Gin Barn houses this rare wood screw cotton press.

data.weatherInfo: Weather in central Louisiana can be unpredictable. Summers are hot and humid. Winter is relatively mild with measurable snowfall every 5-10 years. Average rainfall is approximately 55-60 inches per year. The area is also subject to severe thunderstorms, hail, damaging winds, and tornadoes. Visitors might want to bring hats, umbrellas, and drink plenty of water. Please check the local weather forecast before planning your visit to the park.
data.name: Cane River Creole

data.fullName: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail
data.description: Explore a diverse array of histories contained within El Camino Real de los Tejas’ 150-year life, including the Spanish struggle to missionize American Indian nations, the growth of cattle ranching in the Mexican period, and the movement for Texan independence and statehood.
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites of the El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail over the 2,580-mile historic route that crosses 2 states, and travels into Mexico, to Mexico City.

operatingHours.description: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a route that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operations and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail
El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail

images.title: Mission San Bernardo ruins, Guerrero, Coahuila, Mexico
images.altText: Mexican mission stands in the dirt
images.caption: Construction of the mission church began in 1760 but was never completed. The outstanding ruins are virtually the only visible remains of the complex of missions established in the area. The purpose was to convert Coahuiltecan Indians to Catholicism.

images.title: El Paso de Jacinto/Paso de los Indios, Webb County, Texas
images.altText: lots of greenery along a river; sunflowers in the foreground
images.caption: Around 1746, explorer Jacinto de León discovered a ford that allowed safe passage across the Río Grande in this vicinity; it had probably been used for centuries by American Indians.

images.title: Rancho los Ojuelos, Webb County, Texas
images.altText: stone house ruins; briliant green grasses and trees on the right
images.caption: This national historic district consists of 13 stone houses (several in ruins) constructed from hewn sandstone blocks, chinked and plastered, ranging from rectangular flat roofed Colonial style buildings to hip roofed two room structures. Post-1750s.

images.title: McKinney Falls State Park, Travis County, Texas
images.altText: rock indentations in a dry creek with five people walking under clouds
images.caption: Recent research reveals that in 1716 the expedition of Domingo Ramón followed the left bank of Onion Creek along the western edge of McKinney Falls State Park to its junction with Williamson Creek. You can walk in rock indentations in the creek bed.

images.title: Mission Tejas State Park, Houston County, Texas
images.altText: trail segment indentation with leaves in it, trees along the side
images.caption: This 1.5-mile-long trail segment crosses an area that has remarkable visual integrity. The trail segment courses parallel to State Road 21 and at times crosses the highway.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of El Camino de los Tejas National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: www.weather.gov
data.name: El Camino Real de los Tejas

multimedia.title: Mission Tejas State Park – Place to Visit on the El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail
Lobanillo Swales – Place to visit on El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail

data.fullName: Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
data.description: In Jean Lafitte's day, silver and gold filled a pirate's treasure chest, but today's treasures are people, places, and memories. Discover New Orleans’ rich cultural mix. Learn Cajun traditions from people who live them. Watch an alligator bask on a bayou’s bank. Walk in the footsteps of the men who fought at 1815’s Battle of New Orleans. Follow the link to discover the treasure of Jean Lafitte.
data.directionsInfo: Jean Lafitte's headquarters and the park's French Quarter Visitor Center are located at 419 Decatur Street in New Orleans. There are five other park sites scattered throughout south Louisiana. For information on all of the park sites and visitor centers, see the Directions URL.

exceptions.name: Birthday of Martin Luther King, Jr.

operatingHours.description: Each of Jean Lafitte's six sites is open year-round. See the specific site(s) you want to visit for operating hours and days information.
operatingHours.name: Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve

images.title: Barataria Preserve of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.altText: Spanish moss hangs from live oak tree
images.caption: Spanish moss and lush vegetation provide glimpses of Louisiana's wild wetlands at Jean Lafitte's Barataria Preserve.

images.title: Chalmete Battlefield at Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.altText: An oak tree arches over a cannon-guarded rampart with historic house and American flag in background
images.caption: Chalmette Battlefield's American rampart and cannons still guard the site of the Battle of New Orleans in 1815.

images.title: Chalmette National Cemetery at Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.altText: Setting sun lights up cemetery headstones
images.caption: Established during the Civil War, Chalmette National Cemetery's 14,000+ headstones pay tribute to those buried there.

images.title: French Quarter Visitor Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.altText: Visitor center exhibit titled "Crossroads of Cultures"
images.caption: Hundreds of years of history and thousands of people from all over the world have created New Orleans' distinctive cultural mix.

images.title: Acadian Cultural Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.altText: Model of an early Acadian home sits in a glass case
images.caption: Bringing skills and traditions from Nova Scotia, the Acadian exiles in Louisiana found a new home and a new name---Cajuns.

images.title: Wetlands Acadian Cultural Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.altText: Exhibit case full of musical instruments
images.caption: Acadian (Cajun) music began in cabins and dancehalls and has become famous worldwide.

images.title: Prairie Acadian Cultural Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.altText: guitar sits on a dimly lit porch styled stage
images.caption: The Music Porch at the Prairie Acadian Cultural Center in Eunice, LA

data.weatherInfo: All of the temperatures listed are in degrees Fahrenheit. Note that relative humidity, especially in summer months, can reach 90%, so temperatures can feel 10-20 degrees hotter than the actual temperature. Spring (March, April, May): average high 77, low 61 Summer (June, July, August): average high 89, low 75 Fall (September, October, November): average high 78, low 64 Winter (December, January, February): average high 64, low 48
data.name: Jean Lafitte

data.fullName: New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
data.description: Discover the roots of jazz at the New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park. Located in the heart of the French Quarter, our park offers live performances, exhibits, and programs that celebrate the legacy of America's unique musical art form. Immerse yourself in the vibrant history and culture of jazz, a sound that continues to inspire the world. Join us in preserving and celebrating the music!

emailAddresses.description: Email is generally answered within 48 hours.

data.directionsInfo: The park's operations have moved to the Jean Lafitte NHP&P French Quarter Visitor Center located at 419 Decatur St., New Orleans. The visitor center is open 9:30 am - 4:30 pm, Tuesday through Saturday. The visitor center on Decatur Street, between St. Louis and Conti Streets. We are near the statue of Bienville.

exceptions.name: Birthday of Martin Luther King, Jr.

operatingHours.description:
These are the standard hours for the French Quarter Visitor Center for New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park and the Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve at 419 Decatur St, New Orleans, LA 70130.

The secondary site for New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park (Dutch Alley) at 916 N Peters St, New Orleans, LA 70116, is only open for special events.  Please see our event calendar for details.
operatingHours.name: French Quarter Visitor Center for New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park Hours

images.title: Community Events by New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
images.altText: A young brass band musician plays a trumpet
images.caption: The park works with local partners to share jazz at community events, festivals, and other venues.

images.title: Visitor Center Exhibit at New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
images.altText: Exhibit titled "What Is New Orleans Jazz?"
images.caption: "What is New Orleans Jazz?" A visit to the park's main visitor center at 916 North Peters Street will answer the question.

images.title: Visitor Center Concert at New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
images.altText: Kids and adults playing instruments on a stage
images.caption: Passing jazz traditions from one generation to the next is an important part of the park's mission---and great listening too!

images.title: US Mint Concert by New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
images.altText: Singer with jazz band, including park rangers
images.caption: The park's state-of-the-art concert space at the Old US Mint is the perfect place to enjoy some jazz.

images.title: US Mint Voting Rights Act Program at New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
images.altText: Rangers and others sing and play on a stage
images.caption: Programs like this celebration of the Voting Rights Act bring together history, culture, and music.

data.weatherInfo: All temperatures in degrees Fahrenheit. Note that relative humidity, especially in summer months, can reach 90%, so summertime temperatures can feel 10-20 degrees hotter than actual temperature. Average high & low temperatures by month: January - 62-44 February - 68-51 March - 77-61 April - 81-65 May - 86-69 June - 92-79 July - 97-83 August - 96-83 Sept - 90-74 Oct - 82-65 Nov - 72-53 Dec - 66-50
data.name: New Orleans Jazz

data.description: Now a nearly forgotten culture, Poverty Point at its peak 3,000 years ago was part of an enormous trading network that stretched for hundreds of miles across the continent. It was - and is - also an engineering marvel, the product of five million hours of labor. Explore the culture of a highly sophisticated people who left behind one of North America’s most important archeological sites.
data.directionsInfo: By car, from Interstate 20, take the Delhi exit and travel north on LA 17, east on LA 134 and north on LA 577.

operatingHours.description:
Poverty Point National Monument is managed by the state of Louisiana.

Closed on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day and New Year's Day.
operatingHours.name: Poverty Point World Heritage Site

operatingHours.description: We are closed on Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day.
operatingHours.name: Standard Hours

data.weatherInfo: Summers are sunny, hot, and humid. Winters tend to be mild; however, humid rainy periods occur throughout the year. Sudden and severe thunderstorms are common, so stay alert to weather forecasts. Check with rangers at the Visitor Center and/or USS Cairo Museum for updates on weather patterns. Wear comfortable sportswear appropriate for the season, with walking or hiking shoes recommended.
data.name: Poverty Point

data.description: To Confederate President Jefferson Davis, Vicksburg was the "nailhead that holds the South's two halves together." President Abraham Lincoln remarked "Vicksburg is the key" to victory, and could be the north's lifeline into the south. As the federals closed in on the Fortress City, they were met by a ring of forts with over 170 cannon. The resulting battle would determine the war's outcome.

entranceFees.description: This pass admits the driver and all passengers in a private, non-commercial vehicle to the park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description:
Good for 7 days 

You are purchasing a digital site pass that is valid only for weekly entrance fees at Vicksburg National Military Park. The park requires all visitors to pay an entrance fee except children under 16 years of age. The pass covers entry for one motorcycle and passenger.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description:
Good for 7 days 

You are purchasing a digital site pass that is valid only for weekly entrance fees at Vicksburg National Military Park. The park requires all visitors to pay an entrance fee except children under 16 years of age.  The pass covers entry for one pedestrian or cyclist.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description:
Good for 12 months from the date of purchase 
The pass covers unlimited entry for one vehicle and passengers.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Plane — Closest commercial airport: Jackson, MS, 50 miles to the east. Car — Directions to Vicksburg: From the east — Take Interstate 20 west to Vicksburg, MS. Use exit ramp 4B. Follow Clay Street (US-80) west 0.25 miles to park entrance. From the north — Take Interstate 55 south to Jackson, MS. To save time, use Interstate 220 bypass on west side of Jackson. Take Interstate 20 west to Vicksburg approximately 40 miles. Use exit ramp 4B. Follow Clay Street (US-80) west 0.25 miles to park entrance.

operatingHours.description: The Visitor Center is open 8:30 am to 4:30 pm Wednesday-Sunday. Tour road is open from 8:30 am to 5 pm daily with last vehicle entry at 4:40 pm. Public restrooms are open at the Visitor Center and USS Cairo 7 days a week. Park grounds are open sunrise to sunset daily. Closed Thanksgiving, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center

operatingHours.description: Tour Road is open to vehicles from 8:30 am-5 pm.  Last vehicle entry on the tour road is 4:40 pm. Closed Thanksgiving, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day.
operatingHours.name: Vehicle Access to Tour Road

operatingHours.description: The USS Cairo outdoor exhibit area including the ironclad itself is open 8:30 AM to 4:30 PM daily. Closed Thanksgiving, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day.
operatingHours.name: USS Cairo Outdoor Exhibit Area

exceptions.name: Birthday of Martin Luther King, Jr.

operatingHours.description: The USS Cairo Museum is open 7 days a week from 8:30AM till 4:30PM. Closed Thanksgiving, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day.
operatingHours.name: USS Cairo Museum

operatingHours.description: Park Roads are open to pedestrians and bicyclists from sunrise to sunset.  Tour road is open to vehicles 8:30 am to 5 pm with last entry at 4:40 pm.
operatingHours.name: Vicksburg National Military Park Grounds

images.caption: The Union artillery played a major role in the outcome of the Vicksburg Campaign.

images.caption: Stars gleam behind the Illinois State Memorial.

data.weatherInfo: Spring and fall in Vicksburg are always very pleasant with cool nights and warm, sunny days with temperatures ranging from lows of 40 degrees to highs of 70 degrees. Winter weather in Mississippi is usually mild except for occasional cold air invasions which normally last only a couple of days. Temperatures range from lows of 30 degrees to highs of 50 degrees. In the summer, weather is consistently hot, beginning in the low 70's and climbing to highs ranging from 80-100 degrees in the afternoon.
data.name: Vicksburg
